newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore brewer sees China beer market bloodbath.
newsitem.headline: Singapore brewer sees China beer market bloodbath.

text.p: The battle for China's beer market is brutal and will end in a bloodbath, Singapore's Asia Pacific Breweries Ltd (APB) said on Monday.
"China competition is very intense with over 800 breweries and over 60 international beer joint ventures," chief executive officer Koh Poh Tiong told analysts and reporters.

"There is going to be a bloodbath in China. Every major brewery is facing the problem of low contributions. It is going to be very difficult, very intense," Koh said at a briefing on APB's results for the six months to March 31, 1997.
It would be a long time before APB broke even on its investments in China, Koh said.

Losses before interest and tax from China for the first half sagged to S$6.68 million (US$4.7 million) from S$5.62 million loss in the same period of the previous year. The group's first half pre-tax profit was S$90.06 million,
APB posted a 14.4 percent rise in net profit to Singapore $49.46 million for the first-half 1997.
It said the earnings were boosted by good results in Singapore, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Malaysia and Thailand.

The gains were partly offset by lower profits in Vietnam due to higher depreciation costs and currency devaluations and the start-up losses in Cambodia where a new brewery was commissioned in October 1996.

The company said in a statement accompanying its results that said second-half profits would be significantly lower than the same period a year ago due to start-up losses at its brewery on the Chinese island of Hainan and one in Cambodia.
Koh said overhead costs from its US$34 million Cambodian investment could be "easily recovered in a year or two" but he was not too optimistic about Hainan, where APB invested US$64 million.
"Hainan has a higher overhead. It will be more difficult to recover because of the intense competition from China and lower contributions from low retail prices," Koh said.
The group already has over 50 percent market share in Cambodia, where only one other brewery is operating. Cambodia's beer contribution is the group's third largest after Singapore.
